title: Access symbolic links (created by WSL) in Windows
body: Create a symbolic link (ln -s target_file link_name) in WSL. The sym link works correctly with WSL. While the link is visible in Windows Explorer, attempts to follow (or delete) the link in Windows result in an error that the file is not accessible by the system. Is this by design?

comments.body:
I think this is a very important issue.
Actualy I have a Linux VirtualBox Server to compile/manage javascript - npm - webpack resources and I run PhpStorm from Windows to edit code. I have a shared folder between Windows and VirtualBox. If I can't follow symbolic link in Windows I can't replace VirtualBox by WSL. In VirtualBox I can create symbolic link and follow in Windows.
An example of something broken in the latest fast-ring preview (build 15055.rs2_release.170307-1445) is:

Windows/NTFS symbolic link functionality has been making steady improvements.  The vast majority of *NIX-like symlink functionality is, now, completely compatible.  There is little rationality for this restriction any more, and it is very important for many pieces of distributed software.
No. Symlink implementation is incomplete now.
